additionalTextInformation.author: Elke Anna Werner
additionalTextInformation.text:
‘Like the pendant picture of St Erasmus, which has the features of Cardinal Albrecht of Brandenburg, this panel depicting St Ursula could also be a role portrait. A former theory suggesting that the sitter is Ursula Rehdinger cannot be confirmed. The letters O.M.V.I.A on Ursula’s neckband, referring to „Omnia vincit amor“ (Love vanquishes all) in Virgil’s 10 Eclogue, support the thesis, that it could be a crypto-portrait of a concubine (Leys Schütz?). Erotic connotations are also suggested by the direct eye contact between the two figures and the alignment of the arrow, which like Cupid’s arrow is pointing at Erasmus/Albrecht. […]
The present presentation of both panels as a diptych is probably not authentic. Originally they would have been wing panels of an altarpiece of which the central panel is now lost.’ 
[Elke A. Werner, Exhib. Cat. Berlin 2009, 208-209, No. IV.4]

pageContext.description:
The small panel depicts St Ursula in a fashionable, contemporary dress. She stands in front of a velvet curtain, which is held by an angel. She holds the instrument of her martyrdom, an arrow, in both hands. 
[see Elke A. Werner, Exhib. Cat. Berlin 2009, 208-209, No. IV.4]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 29.2 x 10.4 cm
[Exhib. Cat. Berlin 2009, 208-209, No. IV.4]
pageContext.inscription:
In the nimbus: 'S VRSULA' and in the neckband: 'O.M.V.I.A'

[CDA 2012]

tests.text:
DESCRIPTION

Tools/Material:

- fluid, black medium, brush or possibly quill 



Type/Ductus:

- freehand underdrawing? However some sections appear traced or copied?




- thin lines 



Function:

- relatively binding for the final painted version; lines delineated the main contours and describe essential details and facial features, no representation of volume 






Deviations:

- minor corrections were made to the forms during the painting process 




INTERPRETATION




Attribution: 

- Workshop of Lucas Cranach the Elder 




Comments:


- possibly transferred from a pre-existing design 

[Sandner, Smith-Contini, Heydenreich, cda 2019]
